abstracts.cdata!:
The Romania Municipal Services Project
            had a ratings outcome of satisfactory.  The risk to
            development outcome was low or negligible and both the Bank
            Borrower performance rating was satisfactory.  Lessons
            learned include: (1) If project design entails
            infrastructure investments, new land development, and final
            foot print of all proposed investments is not known upfront,
            as a precaution OP 4.12 should be triggered during project
            design. (2) Countries like Romania (then an EU accession
            country) may not so much need help in developing hardware,
            but may benefit more from the Bank on the software side or
            in creating systems and processes, and capacity through TAs
            and transference of knowledge. (3) Beneficiary assessment
            should be programmed during implementation for projects that
            are designed with the objective of basic services delivery
            such as water and wastewater. (4) Projects implemented at
            lower level of Government (through municipalities) and in a
            decentralized manner, demonstrate strong Borrower commitment
            and ownership, resulting in higher counterpart contribution
            even during a financial crisis. (5) Project lending in Euro
            denomination could avert the currency-associated risk
            adequately during implementation.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Municipal Services
            Project for Romania is to assist the Borrower to meet
            European Union (EU) environmental directives in the water
            and wastewater sector, thereby improving the quality and
            coverage of water and wastewater services, mainly through:
            (i) support of infrastructure development in the
            municipalities of Bucharest and Arad to provide better water
            and wastewater service and improve storm-water management;
            and (ii) preparation of priority water and wastewater
            projects in selected counties. Overall implementation of the
            project is good and the project is likely to achieve its
            objective. As of end-May 2011, a total amount of 98.74
            million (93 percent of the total loan) has been disbursed. A
            nine-month extension of component one is necessary to enable
            the Bucharest Municipality to utilize its undisbursed funds,
            complete the remaining civil works contracts and finance
            supervision consultants under the loan. Delays were due to
            the need for technical and design changes resulting from
            complicated construction conditions which are now resolved,
            problems with issuance of construction permits, and delays
            in transferring counterpart funding from Sector one
            Municipality to the General Municipality. To ensure the
            achievement of the project objectives, agreement has also
            been reached that the Bucharest Municipality will finance
            all additional costs for civil works and consultant services
            beyond December 2011, if the works were still not completed
            by then. This will be the first extension of the project.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Municipal Services
            Project for Romania is to assist the Borrower to meet
            European Union (EU) environmental directives in the water
            and wastewater sector, thereby improving the quality and
            coverage of water and wastewater services, mainly through:
            (i) support of infrastructure development in the
            municipalities of Bucharest and Arad to provide better water
            and wastewater service and improve storm-water management;
            and (ii) preparation of priority water and wastewater
            projects in selected counties. The changes include:
            triggering of a new safeguard, (involuntary resettlement)
            for all three components; ceasing loan financing for
            infrastructure works in the Baneasa area, and reallocating
            remaining funds to other areas of Bucharest where the impact
            is expected to be higher; revising the end-of-project
            outcome targets to reflect the reallocation and increased
            civil works costs in Bucharest; aligning the project
            agreement covenant on selecting the operator in Arad with
            current legislation; reducing the number of counties in
            component three from 11 to 10 and modifying the project
            development objective and end-of-project outcome targets
            accordingly; and introducing additional indicators and
            clarified measures to the results framework. The changes
            will mitigate risks to not achieving the project's
            development objective, and introduce adjustments necessary
            to ensure compliance with the loan and project agreements
            without significantly modifying project outcomes.

repnme.cdata!:
Romania - Municipal Services Project :
            resettlement policy framework

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Municipal Services
            Project for Romania is to directly improve the quality of
            water and wastewater services and reduce flooding of low
            lying city areas where new drainage networks will be built.
            Negative impacts of the project include: acquisition of
            agricultural land and meadow land, affect on buildings, loss
            of standing crops, loss of trees, and loss of other assets.
            Mitigation measures include: 1) cash compensation for
            affected land that it is equal to the replacement cost of
            the lost asset; 2) rehabilitation assistance such as job
            placement, skills training and/or use of alternative
            land/property to re-establish use such as grazing; 3) cash
            compensation for the assets at their replacement value plus
            assistance comprising costs of shifting, allowance until
            first harvest, cash compensation, job placement, or job
            training, transition allowance etc; 4) cash compensation for
            entire structure and other fixed assets without
            depreciation; 5) cash compensation equivalent to the market
            value for the affected crops; and 6) cash compensation for
            any assets affected.

Romania - Municipal Services Project :
